channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Man, 20, is killed and boy, 16, is fighting for life after separate knife attacks
item.description: Police arrested a 14-year-old boy on suspicion of attempted murder after the attack on Chapelhouse Road in Solihull at around 2.40pm today.

item.title: Boris is BACK in Downing Street
item.description: The Prime Minister was pictured entering via the back of Downing Street where he smiled to a security guard before heading inside.

item.title: Africa suffers 40 per cent rise in cases and deaths in past 10 days
item.description: After a slow start, the sudden rise - to more than 30,000 cases - and a similar increase in the number of deaths - to 1,374 - has worried specialists.

item.title: Deserted Nightingale hospitals should be used for elderly patients
item.description: Elderly coronavirus patients in UK care homes should be evacuated to the empty Nightingale hospitals, MP demanded yesterday.

item.title: Carole Baskin's missing ex-husband was 'strangled and thrown out of an airplane', his lawyer claims
item.description: Don Lewis' former lawyer Joseph Fritz claims that his client was murdered and was likely lured to the airport over an aircraft deal, but was then strangled and thrown out of a plane.

item.title: Jamie Oliver plans six-figure revamp at his £6million home a year after restaurant chain collapsed
item.description: The celebrity chef, 44, is applying to add new automatic gates, a new drive and to upgrade the oak-panelled library at 16th Century Spains Hall in Finchingfield, Essex.

item.title: Did Trump storm out of coronavirus briefing after he failed to have CNN reporter banished
item.description: The White House tried to move CNN reporter Kaitlan Collins to the back of the room before Trump started his Friday coronavirus press briefing.

item.title: 413 coronavirus deaths are recorded in UK today - the lowest figure this month
item.description: The UK's coronavirus death toll increased by 413 today - the lowest recorded this month.

item.title: Italy's schools will not reopen until September, PM announces
item.description: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte gave the most detailed outline yet of plans to reopen the economy, in an interview published on Sunday ahead of the government's roadmap out of lockdown.

item.title: Romans invented recycling: Pompeii excavations reveal rubbish was collected, sorted and resold
item.description: Historian Allison Emmerson believes rubbish mounds of broken tiles and plaster found in Pompeii, which was destroyed by Mount Vesuvius in AD79, were intended for 'recycling'.

item.title: Trust in government's handling of covid crisis plummets
item.description: The public opinion poll, conducted by Opinium, shows that Britons are losing trust in the country's leaders, with the government's disapproval rating rising from 26 per cent to 30 per cent.

item.title: Trevor Phillips' role in Covid-19 BAME inquiry criticised
item.description: Harun Khan, secretary general of the Muslim Council of Britain (MCB), said on Saturday that the decision to appoint Mr Phillips to the inquiry was 'insensitive'.
item.media:description: Trevor Phillips has been appointed to review the impact of coronavirus on black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) communities (David Parry/PA)

item.title: Donald Trump wishes 'our great First Lady' Melania a happy 50th birthday
item.description: The Trump family is set to celebrate Melania's golden jubilee birthday in quiet fashion at the White House given nationwide coronavirus lockdowns, according to her chief of staff Stephanie Grisham.

item.title: Trump goes on rant against New York Times
item.description: President Trump called himself the 'hardest working president in history' and went after The New York Times for reporting he's 'angrily' eating hamburgers in bed.

item.title: First ever proof of meteorite killing a man uncovered in 1888 report to Ottoman sultan
item.description: Documents show Ottoman Sultan Abdul Hamid II (left), was informed of a meteorite that killed one man and paralysed another after landing in Sulaymaniyah, Iraq, on August 22, 1888.

item.title: Teenage cyclist killed in village hit-and-run
item.description: Adam Barry, 15, was struck by a car at 9.15pm on Saturday as he cycled along a road just outside Risley in Derbyshire. He was rushed to Queen's Medical Centre but later died from his injuries.
item.media:description: Adam Barry, 15, died following a hit-and-run collision in Risley, Derbyshire (Handout/Derbyshire Police/PA)

item.title: 1,000 people ignore social distancing at Chicago party
item.description: Around 1,000 people ignored coronavirus lockdown orders and packed into an apartment to party in Chicago's West Side on Saturday.

item.title: Personal belongings of an 18 year old soldier killed in the Somme found 90 years later
item.description: Private Tom Ambrose was 'gravely wounded' in the head, leg and arm in 1916. He was rushed to hospital near Calais but died of his injuries. His heartbroken mother hid suitcase inside the loft.

item.title: More people leave their homes and flock to DIY stores and parks despite Covid-19 lockdown
item.description: Shoppers were pictured waiting in long queues at B&Q hardware stores around the country on Sunday before they filled their trolleys with items including plant pots and lawn mowers.

item.title: Paramedics ordered to take more coronavirus sufferers to hospital as 'scorecard' threshold lowered
item.description: The London Ambulance Service has changed how it uses the scorecard, which is called News2 and helps assess whether people who call 999 are at risk of deteriorating from coronavirus.

item.title: 'Britain's oldest daredevil' dies aged 108 after breaking host of world records after turning 100
item.description: Jack Reynolds, of Derbyshire, was known for his age-defying stunts to raise money for charity. He was the oldest person to ride a rollercoaster and get a first tattoo. He has died at the age of 108.

item.title: Ecuador 'victim' of coronavirus finds that her family has been told she died
item.description: An Ecuadorean woman in Guayaquil city learned on Friday that her sister was alive, weeks after cremating a misidentified body.

item.title: Germany's far right party AfD's spokesman is suspended after praising 'Aryan' grandfather
item.description: The longtime spokesman of Germany's far right AfD (Alternative for Germany) party has been suspended amid claims he repeatedly described himself as a fascist and praised his 'Aryan' grandfather.

item.title: Britain sends £2.5million of PPE gear 5,000 miles round the world to St Helena
item.description: The flight has headed for the isolated island in the Atlantic Ocean, which has 4,300 inhabitants. It comes amid reports of crippling shortages within the NHS.

item.title: Doctor creates flashcard system to improve communication
item.description: Anaesthetist Rachael Grimaldi, from Brighton, founded Cardmedic while on maternity leave after reading about a Covid-19 patient who was unable to understand healthcare workers.

item.title: Politicians are hiding behind 'follow the science' mantra, warns scientist
item.description: Professor Hugh Pennington (pictured), a leading microbiologist at Aberdeen University, who helped discover the first coronavirus in the 1960s says ministers are hoping to avoid blame 'if anything goes wrong'.

item.title: EU officials 'watered down report on China's coronavirus fake news campaign under pressure'
item.description: The New York Times and South China Morning Post say the original copy of a report made note of efforts by Xi Jinping's regime to spread false information by 'deflecting' blame for the outbreak of the pandemic.

item.title: Top Russian doctor falls out of 5th floor window during conference about lack of PPE for medics
item.description: Mother-of-two Dr Yelena Nepomnyashchaya, 47, plunged 50ft from an office window in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, after being told her hospital would treat coronavirus patients, despite lack of PPE.

item.title: Mike Tindall leads people doing the 2.6 Challenge in place of the London Marathon
item.description: Mike Tindall, 41, joined thousands of Britons across the country taking part in the 2.6 Challenge in order to fundraise money for charities in place of the event, cancelled because of the coronavirus.

item.title: Mayor Bill de Blasio appoints his wife head of coronavirus racial inequality task force
item.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said Sunday that he believes it will take more than 20 months to fully rebuild New York City and announces different councils that will focus on reopening the Big Apple.

item.title: New York sees 367 deaths in a day - the lowest single-day toll since March 31
item.description: Gov Andrew Cuomo has shared an outline of how businesses could possibly reopen in New York as the state sees 367 deaths in a day, the lowest single-day toll since March 31.

item.title: Anthony Yarde opens up on how boxing is helping him cope with his own coronavirus tragedy
item.description: EXCLUSIVE BY RIATH AL-SAMARRAI: Running in the park has become a blessing for Anthony Yarde to cope with his grief, but the sight of so many people mingling reminds him of the problem.

item.title: Princess Eugenie reads 'Guess How Much I Love You' by Sam McBratney
item.description: Princess Eugenie took part in her mother's daily 'Story time with Fergie and Friends' slot on YouTube on Saturday night , reading 'Guess How Much I Love You' by Sam McBratney.

item.title: Robert Webb told his heart would 'fail' due to undiagnosed condition mirroring the plot of his book
item.description: Robert Webb, 47, had heart surgery for a mitral valve prolapse in October last year after writing his debut novel Come Again. The comedian accelerated the unknown condition with alcohol 'addiction'.

item.title: Katherine Schwarzenegger goes on a bike ride with husband Chris Pratt as it's learned she's pregnant
item.description: It's already been an eventful weekend for Katherine Schwarzenegger and Chris Pratt, as news broke on Saturday that the couple are expecting their first baby together.

item.title: Duchess of Cambridge was 'moved to tears' by stories of frontline staff
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge was 'moved to tears' by the sacrifices of frontline workers, leading the royal couple to launc their mental health support service 'Our Frontline' last week.

item.title: Strictly's Katya Jones left traumatised as 'explicit personal photos are leaked'
item.description: Pro ballroom dancer Katya Jones is said to have been left devastated after explicit photos of her were reportedly leaked.

item.title: Britain's biggest steelmaker Tata Steel seeks taxpayer bailout of £500m
item.description: It was reported the firm approached the UK and Welsh Governments for a £500m funding package after many customers, such as car manufacturers, halted production during the crisis.

item.title: Greggs will reopen some branches to test whether they can operate their 2,050 shops nationwide
item.description: The high street bakery closed temporarily last month to protect customers and staff after the Government ordered all non-essential shops to close.

item.title: Fans react with fury on social media as Floyd Mayweather flouts lockdown rules to go sparring
item.description: Floyd Mayweather has drawn criticism after ignoring lockdown rules to train and spar with members of his team at his boxing gym in Las Vegas on Saturday night.

item.title: Tracker app shows coronavirus was spreading in UK weeks before first case was spotted
item.description: The COVID symptom tracker, designed by scientists at King's College London, has identified 'hundreds' of possible cases in January and some in December.

item.title: Food Secretary George Eustice insists food availability is 'back to normal levels'
item.description: George Eustice (pictured today) said there had been 2.1million timings before the crisis but that figure had ramped up to 2.6million.

item.title: Victoria Beckham brushes off backlash over furloughing staff and shares throwback family snap
item.description: The fashion designer, 46, shared the group photo in which she stood beside husband David and sister Louise Adams.

item.title: Kim's Alive! South Korea says despot Jong-un is NOT dead
item.description: South Korea's foreign policy adviser Chung-in Moon said his country's government position is firmly that the despot is not dead.

item.title: NHS staff form an emotional guard of honour as a great-great-grandmother is discharged
item.description: Elsie Kelsall, from Milton, Staffordshire, is one of oldest people to so far recover from coronavirus. She was met with a guard of honour by NHS staff when she left Haywood Hospital in Burslem.

item.title: Richard Branson 'in race to find buyer' for Virgin Atlantic
item.description: Sir Richard's pursuit of a £500 million UK taxpayer intervention has effectively been shelved, and the airline's focus is now on bringing on new backing from private investors, reports indicate.

item.title: Family-of-four who ditched conventional living to live in a luxury tiny house love social isolation
item.description: A family who built and moved into a second home in their backyard so they could rent out their original house extra cash revealed why they are loving self isolating in their 32 square metre space.

item.title: Pictured: Female guests give lap dances at Moise Kean's lockdown house party
item.description: Everton labelled the behaviour 'unacceptable' after the £27million striker, who earns £53,000 a week, sent footage of himself partying at his Cheshire apartment on social media.

item.title: How to make your own Pizza Express Fiorentina
item.description: Pizza Express has released its recipe for its Fiorentina pizza after the UK High Street favourite closed all its restaurants four weeks ago, amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Experts compare coronavirus crisis to Great Depression and declare it opportunity for change
item.description: Experts compared the coronavirus crisis to the Great Depression in the 1930s. President Franklin D. Roosevelt introduced 'The New Deal', a menu of nationally scaled projects that saved the economy.

item.title: Beijing bans 'uncivilised' behaviour with fines for people who don't cover mouth when coughing
item.description: Beijing's government has increased fines for spitting and littering and warned citizens they must 'dress neatly' in public (pictured, the city) and not expose their torsos during hot weather.
item.media:credit: China News Service via Getty Ima

item.title: Neil Ferguson warns of 100,000 UK coronavirus deaths if 'shielding' approach is used
item.description: The Imperial College epidemiologist said letting the young back to work is not a viable coronavirus lockdown exit strategy. Data from the University of Washington, Seattle, predicted 62,500 deaths.

item.title: 'HMS Bubble': Memo reveals how the Queen and Prince Philip are relying on 22 staff
item.description: A memo from the Queen's master of household Tony Johnstone-Burt, 62, revealed that the Queen, 94, and the Duke of Edinburgh, 98 are isolating with 22 members of staff at Windsor Castle.

item.title: Contact tracing app to be released in weeks could help prevent Covid-19 infections
item.description: Professor Christophe Fraser, from Oxford University's Big Data Institute, said 60 per cent of the UK population - or 40 million - would need to download the app.

item.title: The Queen will video call Princess Charlotte on her fifth birthday next Saturday
item.description: Princess Charlotte is set to spend her fifth birthday in isolation with her parents and brothers at Anmer Hall. A source told the Sun the young royal would also video call her great-grandmother the Queen.

item.title: Britain will be hit with weeks of rain from today as heatwave ends suddenly
item.description: Typical April weather will resume next week, with rain and much lower temperatures on the way. Britons have enjoyed sunshine in recent days. Pictured: A woman on the beach in Kent on Sunday.

item.title: Dua Lipa banks £25 million DOUBLING her annual earnings as pop star gains on the likes of Adele
item.description: Dua Lipa is one step away from making it onto the top 10 richest musical earners on the planet, banking £24.7 million over the past year.

item.title: El Salvador ignores social distancing in jailhouse lockdowns after nation sees 22 murders in a day
item.description: President Nayib Bukele, 38, announced a prison emergency on Friday night, with gang member prisoners forced together. El Salvador suffered its highest murder spike since Bukele took office in June.

item.title: Gary Lineker recalls moment he pooed himself on the pitch in England's opening game at Italia 90
item.description: The striker was ill on the morning of England's Italia 90 opener against the Republic of Ireland, but decided not to tell Sir Bobby Robson to ensure that he wasn't dropped from the team.

item.title: The end of 'Stay Home'? Government 'prepares to ditch' hard-hitting lockdown PR strategy
item.description: Number 10 is planning to scrap adverts bearing its 'stay at home' slogan as it works with Australian strategist Isaac Levido, who masterminded the Tories' election campaign last year.

item.title: Building sites will be allowed to stay open late and at weekends to help construction industry
item.description: Ministers are set to allow temporary changes to help the construction industry 'catch up' on delayed projects, as Taylor Wimpey chief executive Pete Redfern called on an end to lockdown restrictions.

item.title: Beloved Border Collie, 14, had to be put to sleep in the boot of the family's car
item.description: Border Collie Shearer, 14, from Old Isleworth, London, was left struggling to eat as a result of a serious illness and the family were advised he would need to be euthanised.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon declares she is willing to ease lockdown at different rate to rest of UK
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon today made clear she is willing to ease coronavirus lockdown restrictions in Scotland at a different rate to the rest of the UK.

item.title: Dominic Raab admits coronavirus vaccine is 'unlikely to come this year'
item.description: The Foreign Secretary told Sophy Ridge on Sky this morning that a vaccine probably won't be available in 2020. Pictured: Scientists at the University of Oxford are working on a vaccine.

item.title: Dream come true: Brad Pitt plays a fact-checking Dr Fauci on SNL
item.description: The comedy sketch show, which returned for another 'At Home' virtual version, kicked off with Pitt sitting at a desk dressed as Dr. Anthony Fauci dicussing President Trump's recent comments on coronavirus.

item.title: Blogger's easy-to-do recipe reveals how to make KFC's beloved gravy
item.description: A mother has unearthed an easy gravy recipe tasting just like KFC's famous sauce as families across the UK crave the fast food favourite amid the ongoing lockdown.

item.title: Converted water tower with observatory room and private beach up for sale for £1.25m
item.description: This stunning property arranged over four levels at Kingston Gorse on the West Sussex coast features sweeping views, a kitchen with white quartz worktops and four en-suite bedrooms.

item.title: Home-testing coronavirus kits are again unavailable for key workers after just 20 minutes
item.description: Millions of key workers have failed to secure a home testing kit again today after the UK government website stated 'none available' just twenty minutes after the tests were released.

item.title: Premier League and FA 'in dispute' over number of foreign and homegrown players allowed in squads
item.description: The two organisations are currently building a framework for foreign and homegrown players that clubs must abide by after the UK has left the European Union.

item.title: Millions of children in Spain venture out for first time in 42 days for an hour's play
item.description: Millions of children in Spain under the age of 14 are enjoying their first taste of freedom in 42 days as the country relaxes their confinement rules and adults are likely to follow from May 2nd.

item.title: TikTok stars move in together to churn out their 15-second videos to 15MILLION delighted fans
item.description: The stars - Jake Sweet, 22, Shauni Kibby, 19, Lily-Rose Hinton, 20, Katie Franklin, 19, Monty Keates, 17, and Seb Wood, 20 - will film content each day and then answer fans' questions.

item.title: Germany's intensive care bed capacity been key to country's low death rate says foreign minister
item.description: Germany's foreign minister Andreas Michaelis has revealed that the country has 40,000 intensive care beds, 30,000 of which could be used with ventilators.

item.title: Essential workers should be given face masks and public advised to wear them too says BMA
item.description: Dr Chaand Nagpaul, chairman of the British Medical Association, is calling on the Government to ask all members of the public to cover their mouths and noses when going outside.

item.title: Hero fundraiser Captain Tom 'blown away' after being sent 100,000 birthday cards and 1,000 presents
item.description: The army veteran who raised nearly £29million for the NHS by walking 100 lengths of his Bedfordshire garden, has received some 100,000 cards and 1,000 presents ahead of his birthday this week.

item.title: Wellness expert reveals how to improve your relaxation at home
item.description: Exclusive: Helene Cassan, Spa & Wellness Consultant at Heritage Resorts in Mauritius and organiser of the annual Mauritius Wellness Festival, shared her simple six-step guide.

item.title: Feud between Oasis and Blur started after Damon Albarn slept with Liam's girlfriend
item.description: According to The Sun, Noel claimed a lot of drugs were involved: 'Liam and Damon were s****ing the same bird and there was a lot of cocaine involved. That's where the germ of it grew from.'

item.title: Dietitian shares what she really eats in a week - and why you should never trust a 'day on a plate'
item.description: Australian dietitian Lyndi Cohen has offered a look inside her weekly food diary, and revealed why you should never use the 'day on a plate' guide as a benchmark for your diet.

item.title: Photographer captures two widowed penguins hugging in Melbourne
item.description: The two hugging penguins were photographed by Tobias Baumgaertner in Melbourne, and have since gone viral online after he shared the snaps on Instagram.

item.title: Sir Keir Starmer warns Boris Johnson UK 'falling behind' other countries on easing lockdown
item.description: The Labour leader has written to the Prime Minister to urge him to hold an 'adult conversation' with Britons to spell out what they are likely to face next.

item.title: Alaska school board bans five books including the Great Gatsby because they depict rape and incest
item.description: An Alaskan school board has banned The Great Gatsby, Invisible Man, Catch-22, The Things They Carried and I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.

item.title: Disneyland shares their secret recipe for grilled cheese
item.description: Disneyland has shared its secret grilled cheese sandwich recipe for others to make in the comfort of their own home, as the magical theme parks remain closed due to coronavirus restrictions.

item.title: Celebrity facialist Melanie Grant shares the six-step regime EVERY woman should follow in isolation
item.description: The celebrity aesthetician who looks after the likes of Kim Kardashian and Victoria Beckham's complexions has shared the six-step regime every woman should be following in lockdown.

item.title: Savage poem by Lord Longleat's brother calls him an 'egocentric fool'
item.description: An extraordinary poem unearthed by The Mail on Sunday reveals just how ferocious and deep-seated the bust-up between the scions of Longleat House really was.

item.title: Labour Party calls in POLICE to probe claims of a 'stop Corbyn' plot
item.description: Labour chiefs have called in law enforcement as part of an inquiry into claims party HQ staff worked secretly for a Tory election victory. A probe was ordered by the new Labour leader Keir Starmer.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn's brother Piers, 73, leads protest against coronavirus lockdown
item.description: Piers Corbyn spearheaded the rally in Glastonbury, Somerset, against the Government's lockdown, which he said was causing more people to die. He claimed that around 100 attended the protest.

item.title: Britain breaches grim 20,000 death milestone: Another 813 deaths are announced in the UK
item.description: In the daily address to the nation this evening, the Home Secretary said the country was not ready to see an ease in lockdown restrictions which have entered a fifth weekend.

item.title: Five people admitted to A&E after being attacked by crocodiles... in England, NHS figures reveal
item.description: An analysis of hospital admissions in England reveals medics have had to deal with everything from alligator bites to scorpion stings - and even illness brought on by simulated space flight.

item.title: 'I'll always feel like I failed my son': Lorin Lafave on picking up the pieces after Breck's murder
item.description: The horrific murder of 14-year-old Breck Bednar by an online predator shocked the nation - So is it possible to move on from such unimaginable loss?
